abstracts.cdata!:
The Xinjiang Highway Project's
            outcome is rated as satisfactory. Three main lessons were
            drawn from the project: 1) There is a need to adopt a more
            cautious approach to traffic forecasting, particularly on
            toll roads in provinces in China's hinterland, as
            demonstrated by two seemingly contradictory events that
            occurred under the project: Early on, the project was
            modified to allow for the upgrading from 2 lanes to 4 lanes
            of some sections of Turpan-Urumqi-Dahuangshan Highway;
            however later on, it was found that the actual traffic was
            far below expectations, not only the new road but also in
            the whole corridor. 2) Traffic accidents rates in China
            continue to raise serious concerns. One should not
            underestimate the risks, nor should one have too high
            expectations within one single project. 3) The efficiency of
            technical assistance (TA) in Highway Projects has sometimes
            been questioned in terms of high costs and limited
            effectiveness as perceived by some provinces. The TA
            provided for the studies under this project has been
            considered successful by all parties involved in terms of
            outcome, and the ingredients for success appear to be firm
            grounding in a sectoral strategy, supporter from MOC as well
            as the concerned provinces, good selection of local and
            international teams, and appropriate arrangements for the
            conduct of the studies and their dissemination.
